dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So the EU has officially given the UK a flextension until January 31st.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the E U has officially given the U K a flextension until January thirty first.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The EU27 has agreed that it will accept the U.K.s request for a Brexit flextension until 31 January 2020.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Donald Tusk confirmed it on Twitter, which is just… very modern diplomacy, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and Donald Tusk confirmed it on Twitter, which is just... very modern diplomacy, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: EU Council president Donald Tusk tweeted the confirmation on Monday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And this comes after Boris Johnson was basically forced to send that letter asking for more time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And this comes after Boris Johnson was basically forced to send that letter asking for more time.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It comes after British Prime Minister Boris Johnson was forced to send a letter to the EU requesting an extension, after a vote on his Brexit bill was blocked, twice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is wild, because he said he'd rather be dead in a ditch than delay Brexit past October.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is wild, because he said he'd rather be dead in a ditch than delay Brexit past October.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson has previously said he would rather be dead in a ditch than to further delay Topline: EU leaders have agreed to grant the U.K. a three-month delay to Brexit, meaning the October 31 exit deadline has been extended until January 31, 2020, at the latest.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And now he's pushing for a general election in December instead.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And now he's pushing for a general election in December instead.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The move now means Johnson will push for a general election this December, with British lawmakers set to debate the move this afternoon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, lawmakers are debating that this afternoon. It feels like everything's just getting pushed back again and again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, lawmakers are debating that this afternoon. It feels like everything's just getting pushed back again and again.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The move now means Johnson will push for a general election this December, with British lawmakers set to debate the move this afternoon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it's a flextension too, so if Parliament ratifies the deal earlier, they could leave before January.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's a flextension too, so if Parliament ratifies the deal earlier, they could leave before January.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The flextension means that the U.K. would be allowed to leave the EU before January 31, if the British and European Parliaments ratifiy a deal before then.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But given how things have gone so far, uh, I wouldn't hold my breath.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But given how things have gone so far, uh, I wouldn't hold my breath.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: No kidding. They did approve his deal in principle last week though.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No kidding. They did approve his deal in principle last week though.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last week, lawmakers approved Johnsons deal in principle, by voting to approve Johnsons Withdrawal Agreement Bill, which sets out the terms of the U.K.s exit from the EU.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True, but then they rejected his crazy three-day debate timeline, so he paused everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but then they rejected his crazy three-day debate timeline, so he paused everything.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson then paused the deal after lawmakers rejected a short three-day window in which to debate it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And now he's basically saying, okay, I'll let you debate the bill if you agree to an election.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And now he's basically saying, okay, I'll let you debate the bill if you agree to an election.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But for the bill to progress further, Johnson said on Friday that he would allow lawmakers to debate it if they agreed to allowing an election on December 12.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's like political blackmail, but also kind of… only way forward?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like political blackmail, but also kind of... only way forward?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Maybe. But after all these deadlines and drama, it's hard to keep track.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Maybe. But after all these deadlines and drama, it's hard to keep track.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For real. At this point, January 31st just feels like the next placeholder.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For real. At this point, January thirty first just feels like the next placeholder.

artist_script:
EU leaders grant a two-month Brexit delay, pushing the exit deadline to January 31st.
HostA: So the EU has officially given the UK a flextension until January 31st.
HostB: Yeah, and Donald Tusk confirmed it on Twitter, which is just… very modern diplomacy, isn’t it?
HostA: Right? And this comes after Boris Johnson was basically forced to send that letter asking for more time.
HostB: Which is wild, because he said he’d rather be dead in a ditch than delay Brexit past October.
HostA: Exactly! And now he’s pushing for a general election in December instead.
HostB: Yeah, lawmakers are debating that this afternoon. It feels like everything’s just getting pushed back again and again.
HostA: And it’s a flextension too, so if Parliament ratifies the deal earlier, they could leave before January.
HostB: But given how things have gone so far, uh, I wouldn’t hold my breath.
HostA: No kidding. They did approve his deal in principle last week though.
HostB: True, but then they rejected his crazy three-day debate timeline, so he paused everything.
HostA: And now he’s basically saying, okay, I’ll let you debate the bill if you agree to an election.
HostB: It’s like political blackmail, but also kind of… only way forward?
HostA: Maybe. But after all these deadlines and drama, it’s hard to keep track.
HostB: For real. At this point, January 31st just feels like the next placeholder.
